content: The Act titled "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" requires consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to specify conditions for Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations as of October 17, 1988, to engage in gaming activities on certain lands within the state. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes in Oklahoma without reservations to engage in gaming activities on certain lands within the state, subject to specific conditions. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow Indian tribes in Oklahoma to engage in gaming activities on certain lands within the state, subject to specific conditions, including exceptions for Indian lands after consultation with relevant authorities. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow gaming establishments on Indian lands in Oklahoma after consultation with relevant authorities and considering the economic impact. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow gaming establishments on Indian lands in Oklahoma if it benefits the tribe and its members, and does not negatively impact nearby entities within 60 miles. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act amendment allows gaming on Indian lands in Oklahoma within 60 miles, with concurrence of the affected state for validity. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2710) is amended to include provisions regarding the conduct of class II gaming on Indian lands or land taken into trust for tribes. INVESTIGATION AND APPROVAL. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to grant powers to the Chairman and the Commission regarding approval of individuals or entities with financial interest in gaming activities. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act grants the Commission the power to identify the top 10 persons or entities with the highest financial interest in each gaming activity subject to regulation. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act empowers the Commission to identify the top 10 persons or entities with the highest financial interest in regulated gaming activities and conduct background investigations on them. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act allows the Commission to conduct background investigations on key individuals involved in tribal gaming, as determined appropriate by the Commission. The Commission can conduct background investigations on key individuals in tribal gaming, including tribal gaming commissioners, key employees, management officials, and gaming enterprise employees for oversight purposes. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to increase Commission funding from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000 for ongoing oversight of key individuals in tribal gaming. SEC. 5 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to change the use of Indian lands by redesignating sections and adding a new section 21. Before using Indian lands for gaming, tribes must submit an environmental impact statement to the Secretary and obtain consent for the change in land use. The Act and its amendments will not impact any existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulated under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act.
